PhilJS vs SolidJS

PhilJS and SolidJS share a similar fine-grained reactivity model inspired by the same principles. Both offer excellent performance, but PhilJS adds Rust/WASM support and enhanced TypeScript integration.

i

Shared Heritage

PhilJS draws significant inspiration from SolidJS's excellent reactivity model. If you know SolidJS, you'll feel right at home with PhilJS.

What's Similar

  • Fine-grained reactivity: Both use signals for reactive state
  • No Virtual DOM: Direct DOM updates for better performance
  • Automatic tracking: Dependencies tracked without manual arrays
  • JSX syntax: Familiar component authoring
  • Component as setup: Components run once, not on every update

API Comparison

Signals

SolidJS

import { createSignal } from 'solid-js';
 
const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
 
// Read value
console.log(count());
 
// Set value
setCount(5);
setCount(c => c + 1);

PhilJS

import { createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
 
const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
 
// Read value
console.log(count());
 
// Set value
setCount(5);
setCount(c => c + 1);

Effects

SolidJS

import { createEffect, onCleanup } from 'solid-js';
 
createEffect(() => {
  const value = count();
  console.log('Count:', value);
 
  onCleanup(() => {
    console.log('Cleanup');
  });
});

PhilJS

import { createEffect, onCleanup } from 'philjs-core';
 
createEffect(() => {
  const value = count();
  console.log('Count:', value);
 
  onCleanup(() => {
    console.log('Cleanup');
  });
});

Key Differences

Rust and WASM Support

PhilJS provides first-class Rust support with the same reactivity model:

1// PhilJS in Rust - same mental model!
2use philjs::prelude::*;
3 
4#[component]
5fn Counter() -> impl IntoView {
6    let (count, set_count) = create_signal(0);
7 
8    view! {
9        <button on:click=move |_| set_count.update(|n| *n + 1)>
10            "Count: " {count}
11        </button>
12    }
13}
âœ“

Full-Stack Rust

PhilJS is the only signals-based framework with full Rust support, enabling type-safe full-stack development with shared code.

TypeScript Integration

SolidJS

// SolidJS props typing
interface Props {
  name: string;
  age?: number;
}
 
const Component: Component<Props> = (props) => {
  // props.name - works
  // props.age - might be undefined
  return <div>{props.name}</div>;
};

PhilJS

// PhilJS uses standard TypeScript patterns
interface Props {
  name: string;
  age?: number;
}
 
function Component({ name, age = 25 }: Props) {
  // Destructuring with defaults works
  return <div>{name} ({age})</div>;
}
 
// Or with accessors for reactivity
function Component(props: Props) {
  return <div>{props.name}</div>;
}

Store API

SolidJS

import { createStore, produce } from 'solid-js/store';
 
const [state, setState] = createStore({
  user: { name: 'Alice' },
  items: [{ id: 1, done: false }]
});
 
// Path-based update
setState('user', 'name', 'Bob');
 
// With produce (immer-like)
setState(produce(s => {
  s.items[0].done = true;
}));

PhilJS

import { createStore, reconcile } from 'philjs-core';
 
const [state, setState] = createStore({
  user: { name: 'Alice' },
  items: [{ id: 1, done: false }]
});
 
// Path-based update (same API)
setState('user', 'name', 'Bob');
 
// Enhanced array methods
setState('items', 0, 'done', true);
 
// Reconcile for server data
setState('items', reconcile(serverData));

Server-Side Rendering

SolidJS (SolidStart)

// SolidStart server function
"use server";
 
export async function getTodos() {
  const db = await getDb();
  return db.query('SELECT * FROM todos');
}
 
// Usage in component
const [todos] = createResource(getTodos);

PhilJS

// PhilJS server function
import { server$ } from 'philjs-ssr';
 
export const getTodos = server$(async () => {
  const db = await getDb();
  return db.query('SELECT * FROM todos');
});
 
// Identical usage
const [todos] = createResource(getTodos);
 
// Or in Rust with full type safety
#[server]
async fn get_todos() -> Result<Vec<Todo>> {
  db::todos::all().await
}

Islands Architecture

SolidJS

// SolidStart islands mode
// Requires configuration
 
export default function Island() {
  "use client"; // Mark as island
 
  const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
  return <button onClick={() => setCount(c => c + 1)}>
    {count()}
  </button>;
}

PhilJS

// PhilJS islands - explicit and composable
import { Island } from 'philjs-ssr';
 
function Counter() {
  const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
  return <button onClick={() => setCount(c => c + 1)}>
    {count()}
  </button>;
}
 
// Use anywhere
<Island client:visible>
  <Counter />
</Island>
 
<Island client:idle priority="low">
  <HeavyComponent />
</Island>

Ecosystem Comparison

FeatureSolidJSPhilJS
Meta-frameworkSolidStartBuilt-in SSR
Rust SupportNoFirst-class
UI ComponentsCommunity libsphiljs-ui
Forms@modular-forms/solidphiljs-forms
Router@solidjs/routerphiljs-router
DevToolssolid-devtoolsphiljs-devtools

When to Choose Which

Choose SolidJS if:

  • You want a mature, battle-tested framework
  • You need extensive third-party library support
  • You prefer a pure JavaScript/TypeScript stack

Choose PhilJS if:

  • You want Rust/WASM support for performance-critical code
  • You're building full-stack Rust applications
  • You want integrated tooling (forms, UI, routing)
  • You prefer enhanced TypeScript patterns
